Hi Jeff,

There is a relationship between the planetary cycles and the st=
ock and commodity 
market. Because these cycles are known it advance it has=
 predictive value!
99% of people don't believe this even if evidence  prove=
s decisively. You can go 
to Amazon or simply google it to find tons of inf=
ormation. 


Thanks

Peter




________________________________
From: Jeff =
Clune <jeffclune@...>
To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.=
com>
Sent: Fri, 5 November, 2010 15:41:11
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Financial=
 trading with Hyperneat

   
I keep waiting for others to ask this question=
, which tells me I have to be
misinterpreting something....

You keep menti=
oning planetary movements and astrological data. Are you
trying to predict =
the stock market based on the movement of the planets? Why
on earth...;-)..=
..do you think that's a causal variable of predictive value?

Best regards,=

Jeff Clune

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Computational Synthesis Labor=
atory
Cornell University
jeffclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune

**Call =
for papers! Generative and Developmental Systems Track, GECCO 2011
(Dublin)=
. Deadline Jan. 26th.**

ubject: [neat] Re: Financial trading with Hyperneat

> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Peter Henry <blackprinzze@...> =
wrote:
>> 
>> Hello Peter,
>> 
>> Yes it does make sense to try NEAT first,=
 just to get a feel for this. The
>> main 
>> 
>> reason I considered hyper=
NEAT is because the input data would be planetary
>> coordinates, of which =
is geometric in nature. The inputs should total no more
>> than 40, this al=
so includes inter-market forex data. Because future planetary
>> informatio=
n is known in advance this can be used in our forecasts.
>> 
>> Which sourc=
e data Library do you feel is best for this type of task?
>> 
>> Peter 
>> =

>> 
>> 
>> 
>> ________________________________
>> From: petar_chervenski =
<petar_chervenski@...>
>> To: neat@yahoogroups.com
>> Sent: Fri, 5 November=
, 2010 7:37:57
>> Subject: [neat] Re: Financial trading with Hyperneat
>> 
=
>> =C3=82  
>> Hi Peter, 
>> 
>> I'd suggest that you try regular NEAT firs=
t, HyperNEAT may not be neccessary.
>> HyperNEAT is a good choice if the in=
puts are hundreds or thousands in number
>> and/or there is some obvious ge=
ometry in the input space that can be
>> exploited 
> 
>> by arranging the =
positions of the substrate nodes. For financial applications
>> I'd use a s=
mall set of inputs, but very preprocessed data, like what most
>> good 
> 
=
>> custom indicators do, and regular NEAT.
>> 
>> 
>> Peter
>> 
>> --- In n=
eat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tansey@> wrote:
>>> 
>>> Peter,
>>> 
>>=
> I think you'd be better off familiarizing yourself with the details of
>>=
> how HyperNEAT works. Novelty Search is a different algorithm altogether,
=
>>> for a different class of problems. You probably should familiarize
>>> =
yourself with the HyperNEAT algorithm before trying to design an
>>> experi=
ment. The HyperNEAT user's page has a lot of really good
>>> information: h=
ttp://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html
>>> 
>>> I'm not famili=
ar with the EPlex's C++ framework, but SharpNEAT does
>>> provide a GUI. Ho=
wever, it's more of an engineer's GUI, designed to
>>> visualize your exper=
iment after you set it up in code. I tend to find it
>>> easier to just use=
 SharpNEAT in a console application. I've written some
>>> tutorials on how=
 to create a SharpNEAT experiment:
>>> 
>>> http://www.nashcoding.com/2010/=
07/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-with-
>>> sharpneat-2-part-1/
>> /
=
>>> /
>>> 
>>> Hope that helps.
>>> 
>>> Sincerely,
>>> Wesley
>>> 
>>> On =
11/4/2010 10:14 AM, Peter wrote:
>>>> 
>>>> Westley,
>>>> 
>>>> Thanks, Dat=
a presentation is quite important, I understand that
>>>> HyperNEAT is desi=
gn to accept 3D data source, I can add any time frame
>>>> also multple mar=
kets, to refect external market influences.
>>>> 
>>>> Is there currently a=
 GUI interface avilable to input and output data?
>>>> Is there any other c=
onsiderations to take into account with regards ?
>>>> to data presentatati=
on that I must adhere to?
>>>> 
>>>> I notice from the links there is also =
a Novelty search Library
>>>> available, Can this be incorprated within Hyp=
erNeat?
>>>> 
>>>> I would like to get a small project test project quickly=
 what is the
>>>> best way to go around this.
>>>> 
>>>> Sorry I,m a newbie=
 to this, and would be getting techincal assistance.
>>>> But I do understa=
nd the external influences of the forex markets.
>>>> 
>>>> Thanks
>>>> 
>>=
>> Peter
>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>, =
Wesley
>>>> Tansey <tansey@> wrote:
>>>>> 
>>>>> Hi Peter,
>>>>> 
>>>>> I t=
hink if you normalize your data (e.g., in the range [-1,1]), you can
>>>>> =
certainly give it a shot. You need to be careful about overfitting to
>>>>>=
 your data, especially when all you have is daily data. Also, you
>>>> need=
 to
>>>>> be cautious about the fact that you'd be trading a black box.
>>>=
>> 
>>>>> Sounds like a fun project though, best of luck!
>>>>> 
>>>>> Wesl=
ey
>>>>> 
>>>>> On 11/2/2010 10:08 PM, Peter Henry wrote:
>>>>>> [Attachmen=
t(s) <#TopText> from Peter Henry included below]
>>>>>> Hi
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> R=
efer to excel spreadsheet.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> This is what the data looks like =
Columns B to F Is the Open High Low
>>>>>> Close and Volume of our target D=
ata, Column E is the Close prices
>>>> this
>>>>>> is what we are trying to=
 forecast for the following period. Column M
>>>>>> to AP is the Astrologic=
al Data that would be used as inputs, Note the
>>>>>> Astro engine can Gene=
rate data indefinitely into the future, this
>>>>>> can be helpful in our f=
orecasts
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> I hope this is clear
>>>>>> Thanks RegardsPeter
>>>=
>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> -------------------------------------------------------=
---
>>>>>> *From:* Peter Henry <blackprinzze@>
>>>>>> *To:* neat@yahoogroup=
s! .com

>>>>>> *Subject:* Re: =
[neat] Fiancial trading with Hyperneat
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Hello Wesley,
>>>>>> =

>>>>>> Thanks for your response. I'm doing it for fun interest and persona=
l
>>>>>> profit if it works, I'm more fascinated by the prospect both Astro=

>>>> and
>>>>>> AI working together.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> The Swiss Astro Engine=
 is freely available and can generate planetary
>>>>>> information in real =
time. I would initially start with daily price
>>>>>> data then scale it up=
 to Monthly or Hours and minutes.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> The inputs is going to be =
the planetary locations together with the
>>>>>> close prices of target dat=
a.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> I have all the data available in excel format, what the b=
est and
>>>>>> quickest way to carry out some tests?
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>=
 Peter
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> -----------------------------------------------------=
-----
>>>>>> *From:* Wesley Tansey <tansey@>
>>>>>> *To:* neat@yahoogroups.=
com <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com>
>>>>>> *Sent:* Wed, 3 November, 2010 1:=
01:02
>>>>>> *Subject:* Re: [neat] Fiancial trading with Hyperneat
>>>>>> 
=
>>>>>> Hi Peter,
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Maybe you could fill us in a little more. F=
or starters, what's an
>>>>>> Astro Engine? What kind of intervals are you =
trading? What are the
>>>>>> inputs/outputs going to be? What is your data =
set size? How are you
>>>>>> going to prevent over-fitting?
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> =
1. I think it's impossible to say without knowing more.
>>>>>> 2. Not theor=
etically. I suppose at some point, your net gets too slow
>>>>>> to be prac=
tical.
>>>>>> 3. The EPlex C++ framework:
>>>>>> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/so=
ftware.html#gaucij_HyperNEAT
>>>>>> Also, Colin Green's SharpNEAT (C#) fram=
ework:
>>>>>> https://sites.google.com/site/sharpneat/
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Al! s=
o, are you doing this for fun or profit? If you're doing it for
>>>>>> prof=
it, there are a ton of other considerations that you have to take
>>>>>> in=
to account, particularly regarding trading costs and regulations.
>>>>>> 
>=
>>>>> Wesley
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> On 11/2/2010 8:47 PM, Peter Henry wrote:
>>>>>>=
 
>>>>>>> Hello,
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> I would like to create trading indicator =
and systems using
>>>> HyperNEAT,
>>>>>>> input data is going to be fed fro=
m an Astro Engine, up-to 30 inputs
>>>>>>> required and one output.
>>>>>>>=
 
>>>>>>> Can someone please answer the following questions or simply give
=
>>>>>>> there options
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> 1, Does anyone think the HyperNEAT i=
s suitable for such a task
>>>>>>> 2, Is there any restrictions on the amou=
nt of input data that can be
>>>>>>> used.
>>>>>>> 3, What is the best Hype=
rNEAT Software Libraries available
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> The engine is going to =
be used for forecast forex prices using Astro
>>>>>>> and Inter-market data=
. HyperNeat to be used to work out
>>>> relationships
>>>>>>> and predict p=
rices,
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Thanks in advance I will share any results with gro=
up
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Peter
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>> 
>>>> 
>>>=
> 
>>> 
>>
